video.title: Cronos: The New Dawn | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Oh, I see. Getting cocky now, are we, Bloober 
Team? Konami lets you remake Silent Hill 2,

and you went, &quot;Oh boy, we&#39;re in the big leagues 
now! No more inscrutable walking simulators about

the interpersonal issues of depressed Polish 
people trapped in nightmare worlds for us!

We&#39;re Johnny Big Trousers survival horror makers; 
we make games with actual mechanics and combat

and guns. AND interpersonal issues of depressed 
Polish people trapped in nightmare worlds. Oh,

and still inscrutable, of course. That&#39;s 
Eastern Europe for you. Inscrutable art,

tracksuits, bad weather, and no fucking downtown 
parking.&quot; Big fucking talk for a developer named

after an obscure Mario enemy. But one thing 
Bloober Team would have benefited from taking

on board while they were busy remaking Silent Hill 
2 was the virtue of the elevator pitch; that is,

story that can be very easily summarized 
for the sake of piquing interest. I mean,

Silent Hill 2 is &quot;dude gets letter from 
dead wife.&quot; Bam. Intrigue in six words.

Hemingway would be proud. We could 
probably shorten it further, even. &quot;Dude,

dead wife.&quot; &quot;Deadwife.&quot; &quot;Dwuh.&quot; Let&#39;s see how 
quickly we can summarize Bloober Team&#39;s new one.

Cronos: The New Dawn is about an explorer in 
a dead, postapocalyptic Polish city looking

for rifts in space-time so they can go back 
to the pre-apocalypse and suck the brains

out of important people and upload them to 
post-apocalypse Dropbox. Which will in some

way help. And also, she&#39;s a clone or a robot 
or something who goes around wearing a weird,

terrifying environment suit incorporating 
a big dome head with a vagina on the front.

And we look like an astronaut side gigging as 
a living statue performer. And we look like

Mysterio as redesigned by H.R. Giger. And we 
look like the result of an orgy between every

major evil alien race from Doctor Who. I could 
keep going; I&#39;ve got a lot of these. And look,

I&#39;m not saying everything has to be high concept. 
I think it&#39;s perfectly fine to leave the audience

with some unanswered questions. It&#39;s just the 
main unanswered question I came away from Cronos

with was, &quot;What the fuck was that all about?&quot; 
There&#39;s even a twist towards the end that fell

kinda flat because it recontextualized events from 
&quot;inscrutable situation the game didn&#39;t explain

well or take time to make sure I understood&quot; to 
&quot;other inscrutable situation the game didn&#39;t etc.&quot;

Gameplay-wise, at least Cronos has a lot in 
common with the Silent Hill 2-make. It&#39;s a

third-person Resident Evil 4-style camera that 
ravenously craves buttock; lots of slow walking

through spooky abandoned environments, looting 
scraps of ammo and health items, looking for the

puzzle solutions to open up the way to the next 
area with the kind of extremely limited inventory

that never fails to pump aerosolized scrotum sweat 
right up my nostrils. With the classic annoyance

of having a single yale key count for exactly 
the same inventory space as a double-barreled

shotgun. And then there&#39;s a pair of bolt cutters 
you&#39;ve basically got to have on you for the whole

fucking game because chained-up doors keep showing 
up, and there&#39;s no map or guidance system to help

you remember where the fucking things are, and 
that&#39;s where an annoyance officially graduates

to bona fide cuntery. And of course, there&#39;s 
the combat. Funny story, the day after my

first session with the game, I was thinking, &quot;Oh, 
guess I&#39;ll play more of that Bloober Team thing,

explore some more corridors, and shoot some more-&quot; 
and realized in that moment that I&#39;d completely

forgotten what the monsters in the game even were. 
I only had vague recollections of pointing a gun

at something vaguely organic that didn&#39;t look 
like it was about to offer me a French fancy.

So, I reloaded my save and was like, &quot;Oh 
yeah, mutated flesh monsters. I assumed

it&#39;d be something really fucking generic.&quot; The 
comparison to Silent Hill 2-make falls away to be

replaced by a much more valid comparison to Dead 
Space 1-make. You play a protagonist wearing some

kind of overdesigned piece of kitchen equipment on 
their head. You exclusively fight spindly, mutated

monsters composed of mashed-together humans with 
flesh like the last kebab of the evening. There&#39;s

even a gimmick surrounding the monsters in that 
you have to stop them from combining with each

other like a fussy chaperone at a school dance. 
Which is all very well, but it&#39;s another thing

that gets more annoying than exciting when they&#39;re 
doing the nasty like a Cornish pasty and you&#39;re on

the other side of the room trying to extricate 
yourself from three of their wingmen. Also,

there&#39;s an extremely contextual mechanic 
where you can stick to walls and ceilings

and dive across the air to stick to the walls 
opposite, a mechanic that made a lot of sense in

Dead Space—being set on a ruined spaceship where 
gravity is less a law and more a sort of an opt-in

situation—but doesn&#39;t make a whole lot of 
sense in a fucking smashed-up, grimy hospital.

In fact, now that I&#39;m writing all this down, 
Cronos: The New Dawn pretty much is just Dead

Space with a typical Bloober Team plot and 
an infinitely worse title. But the art of

action horror requires a certain balance. 
You have to walk the knife edge of giving

the player enough supplies to get by while 
letting them feel they&#39;re escaping by the

skin of their teeth. This is something Resident 
Evil and Dead Space manage very well. Cronos:

The Neutered Dog does not manage it very 
well. I mean, I died to the very first enemy,

which is never good, as it immediately deflates 
the tension. Between overexuberant monsters and

piddling inventory space, difficulty&#39;s tweaked 
a touch too high early on. I flat-out ran out

of bullets fighting some kebabs in a park at 
one point and just had to leg it to the next

objective. And upon getting there and discovering 
the monsters couldn&#39;t follow me through a door,

presumably because I called base, I was all like, 
&quot;Geez, why didn&#39;t anyone tell me this was an

option?&quot; Until I then had to go back through the 
same park later on and found them all still there,

as well as some new guys who&#39;d spawned 
in to see what all the fuss was about.

And this continued to be more annoying than scary. 
I was dying frequently enough that the tension was

deflating left and right like I was in the kitchen 
of a failing souffle restaurant. And speaking of

more annoying than scary, fucking wall monsters. 
That&#39;s word for word what I wrote in my notes,

actually. Always grabbing you from across 
the room before you&#39;ve even registered their

presence to unavoidably nibble your health 
like a complementary hors d&#39;oeuvre. Hey,

didn&#39;t the Callisto Protocol do the exact same 
thing? Bitch, I wouldn&#39;t even use the same toilet

as Callisto Protocol until I knew hot bleach 
had been applied. I know some of you will be

crying &quot;skill issue&quot; right about now, and still 
more of you will cry &quot;comprehension issue&quot; when

I reiterate that I didn&#39;t get what was going 
on in the story, where the mutation came from,

where our protagonist came from, why there 
were a bunch of space-time rifts around,

or why it was necessary to dress up like a 
Xenomorph-themed stick of roll-on deodorant,

but at the end of the day, an unengaging story can 
be saved by good gameplay, and annoying gameplay

can be saved by a good story, but when you 
have an unengaging story and annoying gameplay,

ain&#39;t no one coming to rescue that. More of 
a &quot;Do Not Resuscitate&quot; situation, really.
